items.name: Apply: QoS: Prioritize Apex Legends (DSCP 46 UDP/TCP)
items.description:
[Focus: Ping / Network, Latency / Input Delay]
Sets a QoS UDP/TCP policy which prioritizes Apex Legends's network traffic by tagging packets with DSCP 46 (Expedited Forwarding). This helps your router process the game's packets first, which can stabilize ping and reduce packet loss on congested networks. Notes:
- Policy is created in the ActiveStore and is fully reversible from Falcon Optimizer.
- Works best if your router respects DSCP tags and your ISP does not strip them.
- If you see any weird network behavior, simply toggle this off to remove the policy.

steps.command: powershell -NoProfile -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -Command "New-NetQosPolicy -Name 'Falcon Apex Legends DSCP46' -AppPathNameMatchCondition '*r5apex.exe' -DSCPAction 46 -PolicyStore ActiveStore -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue"
powershell -NoProfile -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -Command "Remove-NetQosPolicy -Name 'Falcon Apex Legends DSCP46' -PolicyStore ActiveStore -Confirm:$false -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue"

items.name: Apply: QoS: Prioritize Game Traffic (DSCP 46)
items.description:
[Focus: Ping / network stability, jitter, packet loss]
Creates a Windows QoS policy that tags **Apex Legends** packets with DSCP 46 (Expedited Forwarding). If your network gets congested (someone streaming/updates), routers that honor DSCP can schedule game packets first. What to expect:
- Best case: smoother ping under load, fewer spikes.
- Worst case: no change (ISP/router strips DSCP). How to test:
- Turn this on.
- Start a download/stream on the same network.
- Compare in-game ping/jitter with and without. Notes:
- Ethernet usually beats Wi‑Fi for jitter.
- Fully reversible: toggle off removes the policy.

steps.command: powershell -NoProfile -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -Command "New-NetQosPolicy -Name 'Falcon Apex Legends DSCP46' -AppPathNameMatchCondition '*r5apex.exe' -DSCPAction 46 -PolicyStore ActiveStore -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue"
powershell -NoProfile -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -Command "Remove-NetQosPolicy -Name 'Falcon Apex Legends DSCP46' -PolicyStore ActiveStore -Confirm:$false -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue"

items.name: Competitive In‑Game Settings (FPS + Clarity)
items.description:
[Focus: FPS, reduced input delay, visual clarity]
A competitive baseline that usually gives the biggest gains without breaking the game: Display / sync
- Prefer **Fullscreen Exclusive** (if available). If the game only supports borderless, keep it and rely on a good FPS cap.
- **V‑Sync: Off** (adds latency). If tearing bothers you, use an FPS cap instead of V‑Sync.
- **FPS cap:** cap slightly below your refresh (ex: 237 for 240Hz, 162 for 165Hz). This reduces frametime spikes and keeps latency consistent. Graphics (highest ROI)
- Motion blur / depth of field / film grain: **Off**.
- Shadows: **Low/Off** (shadows are one of the most expensive settings).
- Effects/particles/post‑processing: reduce first when fights cause drops.
- Textures: keep within VRAM (too high → hitching). Latency features
- If the game supports **Reflex / Low‑Latency**: enable it. Test On vs On+Boost. Rule:
- Change one cluster at a time, then play 2–3 matches to confirm the gain.

items.name: Windows + Driver Setup (Low‑Latency Baseline)
items.description:
[Focus: input delay / frametime consistency]
This is the “don’t sabotage yourself” checklist: Windows
- Set the correct **monitor refresh rate** in Windows display settings.
- Disable background recording you don’t use (Game Bar captures, DVR features).
- Disable overlays you don’t need (Discord overlay, Steam overlay, GeForce overlay, Overwolf).
- Keep 10–20% free space on the drive the game uses (SSD cache + updates). GPU driver
- Keep drivers reasonably current (not necessarily day‑1 if they’re unstable).
- Prefer a stable driver branch you’ve tested. Network
- Ethernet > Wi‑Fi for jitter.
- If your ping spikes when others use the internet, you likely have **bufferbloat** (router QoS/SQM helps more than any Windows tweak). Performance truth:
- If a “tweak” doesn’t change frametime graphs, it’s probably placebo.

items.name: Launch Options + Config Hygiene (Stutter Reduction)
items.description:
[Focus: stutter reduction / consistent frametimes]
Use launch options sparingly and intentionally: API choice
- Test DX11 vs DX12 (and Vulkan if supported): - DX11 often = smoother on older systems. - DX12 often = higher peak FPS but can stutter during shader compilation. Shader/cache reality
- Clearing shader cache is a **troubleshooting tool**. The first few matches after clearing can stutter more while shaders rebuild. After updates
- Verify game files after major patches.
- If you suddenly stutter after an update, reset only the settings that changed recently. Avoid
- Random “all launch options” lists. Some flags are outdated, ignored, or actively harmful.

items.name: Input Tuning (Mouse / Controller / Polling)
items.description:
[Focus: input delay, consistency]
Mouse
- Turn off Windows mouse acceleration (Enhance Pointer Precision).
- Use a stable DPI + in‑game sens. Avoid constant sens changes.
- Polling rate: 1000Hz is standard. Higher rates can help, but may increase CPU overhead on some rigs—test for micro‑stutter. Controller
- Wired is usually lowest-latency.
- Reduce deadzones as low as stable.
- Disable extra smoothing/filters if the game offers it. Check
- If input feels “floaty” only when FPS drops, it’s a performance issue, not a mouse setting.

items.name: Overlay + Background App Kill‑List (Real FPS Gains)
items.description:
[Focus: real FPS gains]
High-impact background offenders:
- RGB suites (iCUE, Armoury Crate, Mystic Light)
- Browsers with video tabs
- Clip recorders you don’t need
- Cloud sync during play (OneDrive/Dropbox active sync)
- Updaters running in the background Competitive habit
- Before ranked: close everything unnecessary, then launch the game fresh. Why this matters
- CPU spikes and disk spikes cause hitching more than most registry tweaks.

items.name: Troubleshooting Flow (Stutters / Ping Spikes / FPS Drops)
items.description:
[Focus: fast diagnosis]
Use this order so you don’t chase ghosts: 1) Measure
- Use an FPS + frametime overlay. Frametime spikes = “stutter.” 2) Is it GPU or CPU?
- GPU maxed → lower GPU-heavy settings (shadows, effects, resolution scale).
- CPU maxed → reduce view distance / CPU-heavy effects, close background apps. 3) Is it storage?
- If disk usage spikes, you may be on a slow drive or something is scanning/ syncing. 4) Is it network?
- Packet loss/jitter: test Ethernet, reboot router, stop other network traffic. 5) Change one thing
- If you change 10 settings at once, you’ll never know what helped.
